Award.AwardTitle: Planning Grant: Developing a Strategic Plan and Infrastructure Needs Assessment for the CICHAZ Field Station
Award.AbstractNarration:
Texas A&M University is awarded a grant to support the Centro de Investigaciones Cient√≠ficas de las Huastecas "Aguazarca" (CICHAZ: www.cichaz.org) in developing a strategic plan for future improvements to infrastructure to continue to serve a diverse group of international life and social scientists as well as educational and outreach programs. Located in a region of Mexico with high biological and cultural diversity but devoid of academic and research institutions, CICHAZ has become a hub for multi-disciplinary research on social sciences, freshwater ecology, and environmental biology. The current need for CICHAZ is to develop plans for providing the infrastructure and equipment for a contemporary field station that will serve a growing group of researchers as well as outreach efforts. This planning project has two primary objectives: (1) enable CICHAZ personnel to visit established, productive field stations including NSF FSML supported stations and work with their leaders to learn best practices for stations with research and education missions and (2) to hold workshops that will bring together stakeholders from both sides of the US-Mexico border, both education and research backgrounds, and both life science and social science perspectives at CICHAZ in order to develop a strategic plan. Ultimately, the practices learned from visiting other stations together with the workshops will culminate in a 5-year plan and additional long-term objects with landmarks for achieving those objectives.

As an international research station with a strong outreach mission and particular focus on research and educational relationships between the U.S. and Mexico, the broader impacts of the longer-term initiatives of the field station include research experiences for US and Mexican undergraduates and a mentoring program for local junior and high school students. This planning effort will specifically include activities to develop strategy that will help to achieve these goals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this grant was to develop a strategic plan for improving and expanding research, education, and outreach at the CICHAZ field station in the remote Sierra Madre Oriental of central Mexico, through enhancements to facilities and infrastructure.  We did this by bringing together 18 experts in life sciences, social sciences, and conservation from the U.S., Mexico, and the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute in Panama. We also had a dedicated session for local K-12 educators and international science education experts, and a public session where we obtained feedback from local residents. These activities occurred over a four-day panel visit in June 2015, followed by a smaller workshop in June 2016 where we focused on outreach and education activities.  After the 2016 workshop, we conducted a pilot summer camp for elementary-aged children focused on science learning. We also visited a more established field station in the region, Los Tuxtlas in the state of Veracruz, so that we could develop a location-specific plan for improving infrastructure.  The main conclusions were that we should ensure reliable access to broadband internet and clean electricity, and expand the station's housing to separately accommodate short-term and long-term visitors. The information we gleaned from these activities, along with the recommendations of the panelists, are being developed into a full infrastructure proposal to be submitted later this year.
